intro: Rollinia leptopetala var. angustifolia, commonly known as the narrow-leaved star-apple, is a tropical plant native to Central and South America. It is a member of the Anacardiaceae family, characterized by its compound leaves and showy, fragrant flowers. The plant produces small, yellowish-white fruits that are typically eaten raw or used in culinary applications. It thrives in warm, humid climates and is often cultivated for its ornamental value and edible fruits. Its botanical features make it a unique addition to both horticultural and ecological landscapes.
